stream_context.summary: Kaze works on establishing the visual identity for a new level, 'Frantic Fleet Factory'. The stream documents a major creative pivot from an initial volcano/construction concept to an offshore oil rig theme. A significant amount of time is spent programming a custom iridescent oil/water effect and experimenting with color palettes, platform textures, and level structure to overcome N64 performance limitations.

development_findings.summary: The level 'Frantic Fleet Factory' (Course 11) started with the theme of a Bowser-run construction zone.
development_findings.quote: It's called Frantic Fleet Factory and it's a construction zone... It's not really a factory even though it's called Frantic Fleet Factory. It's more like a construction zone.

development_findings.summary: The initial concept was a construction area over a lava pit, heavily inspired by the layout of Rico Harbor from Super Mario Sunshine.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking this is kind of gonna be like Rico Harbor but instead of water it's gonna be lava and the buildings aren't finished.

development_findings.summary: The volcano theme was abandoned because Kaze felt it was too dark and desaturated, violating his principle that a Mario 64 game should be vibrant and colorful.
development_findings.quote: This is Mario 64, the color should be vibrant.

development_findings.summary: The level's theme was pivoted to an offshore oil rig to allow for a more unique and colorful art style, moving away from the initial dark volcano concept.
development_findings.quote: So this is gonna be an oil rig on the sea then. That kind of works for me. That gives us some good color.

development_findings.summary: The level has a strong narrative tie-in, taking place at Bowser's airship factory immediately after the player destroys his fleet in the preceding Bowser level.
development_findings.quote: This is especially funny, because this is course 11. And in the second Bowser level, which is the level right before this, you destroy his entire fleet, right? So now you go back to where the ships were actually built.

development_findings.summary: A significant part of the stream was dedicated to Kaze programming a custom visual effect for the oil surface, creating a dynamic, iridescent rainbow sheen using procedural generation and complex display list commands.
development_findings.quote: When Kay says he has a sick idea, that means we're gonna be watching 45 minutes of VFX attempts.

development_findings.summary: To improve the oil effect, Kaze decided to double the number of vertices on the water plane, consciously accepting a significant performance cost for a much better visual result.
development_findings.quote: I'm gonna admit, that looks cool. Man, this actually looks so much better. Maybe we just go with this. Maybe we just power through it.

development_findings.summary: To manage the N64's polygon limits, the level layout was redesigned from one large, open platform into four distinct areas connected by warp pipes, preventing the game from slowing down.
development_findings.quote: If we make this area like this there's gonna be a shit ton of geometry... but if we have long pipes over here... you go into one and you come out on like another part of the oil rig that will work.

development_findings.summary: The level's missions, which involve Bowser's minions going on strike, were already planned, and the art style development had to work within those existing gameplay and narrative constraints.
development_findings.quote: The missions are decided, the basic layout is decided, right now we're thinking about how to make this look good.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that creating a major SM64 hack requires an obsessive, almost 'mentally ill' level of dedication due to the immense unpaid effort involved.
context_findings.quote: If you want to finish a March 64 major hack you need to be mentally ill. You cannot do it if you are not mentally ill. What kind of normal person would just make an entire hack like that for free?

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes his creative process as an emotional cycle of initial failure and despair followed by breakthroughs that lead to intense excitement and confidence.
context_findings.quote: You start making a level and you feel like, wow, this is dogshit, this is garbage, this is not working out at all. And then you get a few ideas and suddenly it's like, ah, shit, this is gonna be the best thing ever.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a pragmatic and results-oriented philosophy on graphics development, viewing it as a process of iterative experimentation rather than a formal, rigid discipline.
context_findings.quote: That's all graphics is, you just make up some bullshit and then it looks good.

context_findings.summary: Kaze highly values conciseness as a skill, applying it to his own communication, such as refining his tweets to be as impactful as possible.
context_findings.quote: Being concise is one of the most important skills in the world. The more concise you can be with your words, the more information you can put into a single sentence, the cooler it is.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned past conflict with another modder named Skellex, describing it as 'childish drama' and noting that it led to Skellex leaving the scene.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a key suggestion to use black water with orange highlights, which prompted Kaze to experiment with the oil VFX that became central to the level's identity.
biobak.quote: Black water with orange highlights would look sick as hell.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested that the rainbow oil effect should always be partially visible instead of fading to zero, a change Kaze implemented after finding it looked much better.
biobak.quote: I think Biobak was onto something.

biobak.summary: Kaze states that Biobak generally helps with level visuals, confirming his role in providing artistic feedback.

badub.summary: Kaze provided Badub (and the chat) with a vibe-based brief for the level's music, listing keywords like 'evil', 'Bowser', 'construction', and also 'goofy'.
badub.quote: Uh, evil, bowser, construction. Those are, like, the key words.

zeina.summary: Zeina, Kaze's wife and the project's animator, joined the chat near the end of the stream, and Kaze updated her on the major thematic shift of the level.
zeina.quote: Hello Zeina, oh, this is not a lava level. You need to stay tuned for a bit to get what this is.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentioned he is watching Breaking Bad with Zeina, indicating shared downtime outside of the project.
Kaze and Zeina coordinated their dinner plans with her family live on stream, offering a brief glimpse into their personal life dynamic.

key_stories.title: From Volcano to Oil Rig
key_stories.summary: The level's core theme was pivoted from a generic volcano to a unique oil rig. This change was driven by Kaze's desire for a more vibrant, Mario-appropriate art style and resulted in a stronger, more coherent level identity.
key_stories.challenge: The initial concept for 'Frantic Fleet Factory' as a volcano construction zone was proving to be visually dull, dark, and too similar to other lava levels in the game.
key_stories.process: Kaze recognized the volcano theme was failing. After dismissing inspirations like Skyward Sword as too desaturated, he began brainstorming alternatives for the hazardous pit. The idea of an oil sea was raised, which Kaze embraced, immediately realizing its potential for color and narrative consistency with an industrial, ship-building factory.
key_stories.outcome: The theme was completely changed to an offshore oil rig. This new concept provided a stronger narrative link (a place to fuel Bowser's fleet) and opened up a much more vibrant and unique color palette (purple, yellow, and iridescent oil), solving the original design problem.
key_stories.key_quote: How do we make a bright-looking volcano level, though? Can there be more colors?

key_stories.title: Crafting the Iridescent Oil
key_stories.summary: Kaze undertook a deep dive into programming a custom VFX for the level's oil sea. Through trial, error, and a key decision to prioritize visuals over performance, he created a unique iridescent oil slick effect that became a defining feature of the level's art style.
key_stories.challenge: A simple flat texture for the sea of oil would be boring. Kaze wanted to create a dynamic, iridescent effect reminiscent of an oil slick, which isn't possible with standard SM64 water effects.
key_stories.process: Kaze dove into low-level graphics programming, writing custom microcode. He iteratively tested color combinations, blending modes, and mathematical formulas for wave motion. After feedback from Biobak and his own experimentation, he doubled the water plane's vertex count, accepting the performance trade-off because the visual result was so much better.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully programmed a complex, custom visual effect that renders a dark, wavy surface with dynamic, rainbow-colored sparkles. Despite concerns about performance, he chose to increase the geometry to make the effect finer and more impressive, creating a signature look for the level.
key_stories.key_quote: I actually have to increase the draw distance here just so it looks semi-okay. Let's try an oil water effect first, because I just had a sick idea.

open_questions.context: Kaze outlined a detailed storyline for the level involving Bowser's minions going on strike, and Bowser sending a boss to break it up. This narrative seems central to the mission design.
questions: Where did the idea for a minion labor strike come from?
How do you plan to communicate this narrative to the player through gameplay and environmental storytelling, rather than text?
How did this pre-defined story constrain or inspire the level's layout and visual design?

open_questions.context: Kaze constantly weighed visual fidelity against the N64's performance limits. He consciously chose to double the oil effect's polygon count for a better look and redesigned the entire level into four parts to manage geometry.
questions: Can you walk us through your thought process when deciding to sacrifice framerate for a better visual effect?
How do the N64's technical limitations force you to be more creative with level design, like splitting the oil rig into four distinct zones?
What are some other examples where a technical constraint led to an interesting design choice?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he is married to the project's animator, Zeina. They coordinated personal plans during the stream, showing an intersection of their work and private lives.
questions: How do you two manage the dynamic of being both primary creative partners and spouses?
What is the process for giving and receiving critical feedback on each other's work?
How do you establish boundaries between 'work time' on the project and your personal life together?

open_questions.context: Kaze gave a very brief, vibe-based description of the music he wants for the level ('evil, bowser, construction, goofy'). This is presumably the starting point for the composer, Badub.
questions: Badub, how do you translate a list of keywords from Kaze into a full musical composition?
Kaze, what does the feedback loop with Badub look like? How many iterations does a track typically go through?
Can you share an example of a track from a previous level and how it evolved from the initial idea to the final version?
